conclusion: Determine the power of the external force doing work by considering the forces acting on the conductor rod and the work done by these forces.

Identify the forces: The conductor rod is rotating with an angular velocity ω, the magnetic field is uniform with intensity B, the conductor frame is smooth with negligible resistance, and a resistor R is connected between O and C.
The magnetic force on the conductor rod is given by F = BIL, where L is the length of the conductor rod.
The magnetic field B is uniform, and the length L of the conductor rod is not provided. The magnetic force will be perpendicular to the direction of rotation.
The work done by the magnetic force is given by W = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass of the conductor rod and v is the velocity of the conductor rod.
The velocity v of the conductor rod can be found using v = ωr, where r is the radius of the conductor frame.
Substituting v = ωr into the equation for work done by the magnetic force, we get W = 1/2 m(ωr)^2 = 1/2 mω^2 r^2.
The power P of the external force doing work is given by P = W/t, where t is the time taken for the conductor rod to complete one full rotation.
Since the conductor rod completes one full rotation in T = 2πr/ω, the power P is given by P = 1/2 mω^2 r^2 * 1/T.
Substituting T = 2πr/ω into the equation for power, we get P = 1/2 mω^2 r^2 * 1/(2πr/ω) = 1/2 mω^2 * 1/ω = 1/2 m.
The power of the external force doing work is 1/2 m.
